body.p: The boards decided that if the sale and repurchase agreement resulted in an entity’s obligation to repurchase the asset at a customer’s request (ie a put option), the customer would obtain control of the asset because the customer is neither obliged to return the asset nor obliged to stand ready to do so. Consequently, the customer has the ability to direct the use of, and obtain substantially all of the remaining benefits from, the asset (ie the customer can sell, use up or consume the entire asset and choose not to exercise the put option). The boards decided that the entity should account for its obligation to stand ready to repurchase the asset, to be consistent with the accounting for the sale of a product with a right of return (see paragraphs BC363–BC367). That results in the entity recognising the following:

li.p: a liability for its obligation to repurchase the asset, measured at the amount of the consideration expected to be paid to the customer;
an asset for the entity’s right to receive that asset upon settling that liability, measured at an amount that may or may not equal the entity’s previous carrying value of the asset; and
revenue on transfer of the asset for the difference between the sales price of the asset and the liability recognised for the obligation to repurchase the asset.
